stream_context.summary: Kaze reworks a sub-area of 'Divine Dino Domain' (Course 2), replacing a disliked section with a new platforming layout. He is in the 'blockout phase,' using primitive shapes to establish fun gameplay before focusing on aesthetics. The stream also covers future level plans, technical bugs, his YouTube strategy, and a running joke about a bad haircut from Zeina.

development_findings.summary: The project is estimated to be just over 80% complete, with three courses left to finish: 13, 14, and 15.
Kaze's level design process prioritizes gameplay, using a 'blockout phase' with primitive shapes to perfect platforming and flow before any aesthetic work like modeling or texturing begins.
development_findings.quote: We're just kinda trying to make the platforming fun. And then after we have the platforming, we're gonna work on the aesthetic.

development_findings.summary: The themes for the next two levels are set, with Course 13 being a mysterious ice castle and Course 14 a space arcade. Course 15's theme is still undecided.
development_findings.quote: Course 13 is going to be probably an ice castle, like a mysterious type ice castle... And course 14 is going to be a space arcade.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical bug exists where interacting with water can crash the game due to an incomplete engine update to a 'new step function'.
development_findings.quote: Water hasn't been updated to the new step function yet and the old step functions are not fully supported anymore, so being in water can just crash the game.

development_findings.summary: The project uses a decompilation base, which, unlike older binary hacking methods, forces all level areas to be loaded into RAM at once, creating memory constraints.
Kaze uses Git as his primary backup system for all project files, including 3D models, taking advantage of the small file sizes inherent to N64 development.
development_findings.quote: I just backup all important files on Git, cause I work with N64, all my files are below 100 megabytes, so it's fine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals he is expecting a child with Zeina, which will likely impact his development schedule and his ability to host the 'F3' community event.
context_findings.quote: I'm gonna have a child coming out around the same time as F3 would usually be happening. So it's a little tight time-wise for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze consciously avoids offering Patreon-exclusive downloads or bonuses for his projects to mitigate potential legal risks from Nintendo.
context_findings.quote: I also don't give out any Patreon bonuses. Because that might get me in legal trouble with Nintendo. So I stay away from that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrates a savvy understanding of content creation strategy, changing a video title to something more provocative ('Nintendo's biggest lie') purely to increase the click-through rate.
context_findings.quote: What matters is that we have a YouTube title. This is how YouTubers think, by the way. That's how you have to think as a YouTuber.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's learning philosophy is to read official documentation and practice using hotkeys directly, which he believes is superior to watching video tutorials.
context_findings.quote: All the tutorials people make on Blender are just a less efficient way to just reading their documentation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a dislike for going to barbers, citing the time and money spent as reasons he and Zeina cut his hair at home.
context_findings.quote: Barbers, you waste so much time. Second of all, they cost money. And third of all, I'm a guy who cares what I look like.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions a feature or workflow in their tools called 'Biobak snapping', indicating a difference in style or preference between them.
biobak.quote: Dude, I hate Biobak snapping. It feels so uncontrollable.

zeina.summary: Kaze is waiting on a few more animations from Zeina to be able to finalize and ship Course 12.
Zeina accidentally shaved a bald patch onto Kaze's head while cutting his hair, an incident which became a recurring, humorous topic throughout the stream.
zeina.quote: The fucking hair clipper thing fell off and she just kept going. Now there's a huge bald line on my head with no hair.

zeina.summary: A brief exchange reveals a personal dynamic where Kaze admits to having a double standard about hairstyles, stating he wouldn't let Zeina have short hair.
zeina.quote: Would I let Zeina go bald? No, that would look awful. But that's double standards, Kaze. Yeah, so what? Cry about it.

key_stories.title: The Haircut Reveal
key_stories.summary: After Zeina messed up his haircut, Kaze initially hid it under a beanie. He then turned the situation into an interactive stream event, eventually revealing the bad haircut in exchange for viewer subscriptions, monetizing a personal and humorous misfortune.
key_stories.challenge: Zeina accidentally shaved a bald line into Kaze's head while cutting his hair, making him self-conscious about his appearance on stream.
key_stories.process: Kaze wore a beanie to hide the haircut, sparking curiosity from his viewers. He then turned his misfortune into an interactive event, agreeing to gradually lift the beanie in exchange for subscriptions, before the full reveal.
key_stories.outcome: He eventually revealed the haircut to the chat's amusement. The incident became a running joke and provided a candid, humorous look into his personal life and relationship with Zeina.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, here you go. My fucked up haircut. You see that? There's just the fucking bald line here.

key_stories.title: The YouTube Algorithm Gambit
key_stories.summary: Noticing a new video's poor performance, Kaze analyzed its metrics on stream and decided the title was the problem. He changed it to the much more provocative 'Nintendo's biggest lie' to improve the click-through rate, explaining that the 'angle' is crucial for YouTube success.
key_stories.challenge: A new video Kaze uploaded to his clips channel was underperforming with a low click-through rate.
key_stories.process: Kaze checked the analytics live on stream, saw the low 7.4% CTR, and decided the title was the problem. He brainstormed a new, more provocative title, changing it from a descriptive one to 'Nintendo's biggest lie' to create intrigue.
key_stories.outcome: He successfully changed the title and planned to monitor the analytics to see if his gambit worked. The story demonstrates his practical understanding of YouTube as a platform and his willingness to use provocative tactics for growth.
key_stories.key_quote: Nintendo's biggest lie. Oh my god. That's fucking insane. This is an insane title. Watch this go to like 20% click-through rate.

key_stories.title: Reworking a 'Sucky' Level
key_stories.summary: Kaze decided a section of an existing level was not fun to play. During the stream, he completely scrapped the old design and began blocking out a new 'platforming playground' from scratch, showcasing his process of prioritizing gameplay feel over aesthetics in early design.
key_stories.challenge: A sub-area in an older level, Divine Dino Domain, used an 'almost autoscroll section' that Kaze 'realized... sucked.'
key_stories.process: Kaze deleted the old geometry and began a 'blockout phase' using primitive shapes. He live-designed new platforming paths, spiral staircases, and traversal options, focusing entirely on making the movement and layout feel good before considering visuals.
key_stories.outcome: The area is being completely redesigned from the ground up to be a more engaging 'platforming playground,' demonstrating his iterative design philosophy and commitment to fun over preserving old work.
key_stories.key_quote: I realized the section sucked. So now we have a little bit of a platforming playground here.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he has already started work on Course 14 but cannot show it because it's 'part of the compact' and 'Eiza doesn't want me to show it'.
questions: What is the 'compact' you referred to regarding Course 14?
Who is Eiza, and are they a new collaborator?
What are the terms of this agreement and why does it require secrecy for this specific level?

open_questions.context: Kaze explicitly stated he avoids offering Patreon bonuses because it 'might get me in legal trouble with Nintendo'.
questions: Could you elaborate on your personal strategy for avoiding legal issues with Nintendo?
Is this policy based on specific legal advice, community precedent, or your own assessment of the risk?
Have you ever had any interactions, direct or indirect, with Nintendo that have shaped this approach?

open_questions.topic: Core Engine Change: The 'New Step Function'
open_questions.context: Kaze identified a game-crashing bug with water, explaining it's because the water code hasn't been updated to a 'new step function' and older functions are no longer supported.
questions: What technically is this 'new step function'?
What prompted this fundamental change in the game's engine?
What were the challenges in implementing it, and what other game systems did it affect?

open_questions.context: Kaze said he might not be able to host the 'F3' event this year because he and Zeina are expecting a child around the same time.
questions: What is F3, and what has your role in organizing it been in the past?
How do you anticipate becoming a father will change your approach to development, streaming, and community involvement?
What are your hopes or fears about balancing this new chapter of your life with your creative work?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he needs a boss for the 'Mysterious Ice Castle' in Course 13 and asked the chat to brainstorm ideas.
questions: What are your own initial ideas for the ice castle boss?
What design elements make a boss feel 'mysterious' or 'suspenseful' to you?
Can you walk me through an example of how you've incorporated a community suggestion into your design process in the past?
